name: Edward the Elder's Burh at Manchester (919 AD)
description: In 919 AD, King Edward the Elder sent forces to repair and garrison 'Mameceastre' as a fortified burh against the Vikings. The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle records this as the first mention of Manchester in 500 years.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find archaeological reconstructions of the 919 burh.

Anglo-Saxon Chronicle entry (919 AD):
'King Edward went with the army to Thelwall and ordered the burh to be built and
occupied and manned; and he ordered another army, also from the people of Mercia,
to occupy Manchester in Northumbria, and repair and man it.'

Likely location: Castlefield area (reusing Roman fort site) or near the cathedral.
Some scholars suggest the burh was at the confluence of Irwell and Irk.

Possible sources for reconstruction plans:
- 'Anglo-Saxon Fortifications' by David Hill & Alexander Rumble (2009)
- 'Manchester: An Archaeological History' or similar
- Greater Manchester Archaeological Unit publications
- Current Archaeology magazine may have covered this
- Proceedings of the Lancashire & Cheshire Antiquarian Society

Key question: Was the Roman fort site reused, or was the burh built elsewhere?
